attachments.title: Understand the Basics of HTTP    - Course by @petejohanson
attachments.text: In this course, we will learn the fundamentals of the Hypertext Transport Protocol (HTTP) by exploring several popular HTTP APIs such as the GitHub API. Starting with the basic structure of an HTTP request and response, we will then delve into the specifics of each element of the request/response messages. Using concrete examples from these APIs, we will cover request methods, response status codes, messages headers, and message bodies. Along the way, you'll learn about specific message headers, such as `Cache-Control`, and `Cookie` and how they control the behavior of clients/browsers and HTTP API services. This course uses HTTPie, if you would like to follow along with the instructor you can download the client [here](<https://httpie.org/>).

You can do anything AI will do as far as I know. I found the easiest way to install the latest version was via:

brew install caskformula/caskformula/inkscape

but it did take 28 minutes to build on my i7. It is however worth the wait to get the latest version of goodness.
BUT do people make funny gifs with inkscape?
And I LOVE free!

I used AI for years until I found Inkscape, the transition is definitely more of a challenge if you are used to working in AI. As with any vector art software package you'll need to wrap your head around the concept of different curve types and how to manipulate them. Each package has it's own approach of performing manipulations. Inkscape’s docs are really helpful, and there are likely many UTube resources. The bottom line is that open-source applications such as Inkscape and Gimp can do everything Adobe Creative Suite can do - but they are free!

My heroku deployment checklist (CLI, or Command Line Interface - example). 

*1. Make sure you've got the Heroku CLI installed, you can do this with Brew.*
`brew install heroku`
*2. After making sure you've installed heroku, make a sign-up on Heroku, then login via CLI.*
<https://signup.heroku.com/>, and then type into your terminal: `heroku`. 
-- make sure you login on the CLI with the same thing you just signed up with on the site. 
*3. Create your Heroku project in the root folder of your repository, it must have GIT initialized.*
`heroku create <project_name>`
*4. Then, add on the PostgreSQL add-on. Same root directory you were in on step 3.*
`heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql:hobby-dev`
-- if you want to go to a higher plan, change the 'hobby-dev' part. 
*5. Make sure you've got the 'dotenv' package from npm, and configured it in your server.*
`npm install --save dotenv` and in the server.js near the top, `require('dotenv').config();`.
*6. Now, configure your Knexfile.js. Go into the file and add this to production info.*
```production: {
    client: 'pg',
    connection: process.env.DATABASE_URL
}```
*7. Before pushing, set your node version to your current working/dev node version in package.json.*
```"engine": {
    "node": 7.1.0 (or whatever yours is).
}```
*8. Now, make sure "npm start" is set up to node, instead of nodemon. Nodemon does not work.*
```"scripts": {
    "start": "node server.js"
}```
*9. Finally, you can now push your repo to Heroku and it should work. Steps to do this...*
```gaa / git add -A
gcmsg <msg> / git commit -m <msg>
git push heroku master```
*10. After you're done deploying, and troubleshooting any errors... run your migrations/seeds. On terminal:*
`heroku run knex migrate:latest && heroku run knex seed:run`

You should now be deployed and your site should be working! If anyone has any questions, lemme know. That's just my workflow, some others probably access the site instead of doing everything on the CLI, etc... just thought I'd share! Good luck. :slightly_smiling_face:

sexy angular trick #10345:

If you're binding a variable that relies on a promise into a child component, and try to use that bound variable in the child component's $onInit, you may find that the value sometimes isn't there yet. This is because $onInit does not wait for bindings to resolve before running the rest of its code.

The super-sexy way to deal with this is, when you call the child component from your parent component's template, use ng-if to force it to wait on the bound variable, like so:

<child-component ng-if="$ctrl.promise" bound-variable="$ctrl.promse"></child-component>

This way, the child-component waits to render until the variable exists, then passes the resolved variable as normal.

```knex('projects')
.select('projects.id', 'images.url', 'videos.url', 'tags.name')
.innerJoin('images', 'images.project_id', 'projects.id')

At a glance it looks like your res.send happens inside the .then off your first knex statement. Which ultimately makes it concurrent with your promise all. The only way it would wait on your promise all to finish is if it occurred in a .then off of the promise all.

attachments.title: Why and How Physical Activity Promotes Experience-Induced Brain Plasticity
attachments.text: Adult hippocampal neurogenesis is an unusual case of brain plasticity, since new neurons (and not just neurites and synapses) are added to the network in an activity-dependent way. At the behavioral level the plasticity-inducing stimuli include both physical and cognitive activity. In reductionistic animal studies these types of activity can be studied separately in paradigms like voluntary wheel running and environmental enrichment. In both of these, adult neurogenesis is increased but the net effect is primarily due to different mechanisms at the cellular level. Locomotion appears to stimulate the precursor cells, from which adult neurogenesis originates, to increased proliferation and maintenance over time, whereas environmental enrichment, as well as learning, predominantly promotes survival of immature neurons, that is the progeny of the proliferating precursor cells. Surprisingly, these effects are additive: boosting the potential for adult neurogenesis by physical activity increases the recruitment of cells following cognitive stimulation in an enriched environment. Why is that? We argue that locomotion actually serves as an intrinsic feedback mechanism, signaling to the brain, including its neural precursor cells, that the likelihood of cognitive challenges increases. In the wild (other than in front of a TV), no separation of physical and cognitive activity occurs. Physical activity might thus be much more than a generally healthy garnish to leading “an active lif...

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HATEOAS>

attachments.text:
HATEOAS, an abbreviation for Hypermedia As The Engine Of Application State, is a constraint of the REST application architecture that distinguishes it from most other network application architectures. The principle is that a client interacts with a network application entirely through hypermedia provided dynamically by application servers. A REST client needs no prior knowledge about how to interact with any particular application or server beyond a generic understanding of hypermedia. By contrast, in some service-oriented architectures (SOA), clients and servers interact through a fixed interface shared through documentation or an interface description language (IDL).
The HATEOAS constraint decouples client and server in a way that allows the server functionality to evolve independently.

  var x = this.eq(0);
  this.splice(0,1);

};

Thank you so much <@U1V0JV17X>! Several ideas here that I’m going to explore!

Ah, the solutions I can think of offhand are:
* if you have the images locally, you optimize them before pushing to production
* if you are getting images from another site, check to see if they offer optimized/smaller versions (so Harvard Art falls into that category)
* if you are getting images from another site consider sending the images through another API that does image manipulation and will return an optimized version for you (<http://cloudinary.com|cloudinary.com> has this, but their API can be a nightmare, I’m sure there are other options out there).

I would consider the solution to this a stretch goal though. Get everything else working and then work on optimizing images (unless load times are unbearably slow). Make sure there is alt text for all of your images so the user is not looking at a completely blank page. Also consider other content that *can* load sooner and keep the user occupied (which it sounds like you are exploring). Even a “loading” gif will buy you a few seconds.
Harvard Art, which does, and Rijksmuseum, which does not.

At my last job we did feature branches with pull requests just like what Mat described. One benefit to using pull requests for merging feature branches was that we could have a comment thread about the changes being made and any issues could be smoothed out before the code was merged into master.
There are different philosophies on this, but typically master is supposed to be clean and releasable at any time, so limiting who can merge in and when is important.

Yes pull requests are commonly used for branches.  A typical workflow would have a single person/group responsible for master.  Other devs would issue a pull request when they wanted their branch merged in.

Anna’s understanding is mine, as well: pull requests are used for situations in which you have forked a repo and want to alert the owner of the original repo that you have changes you would like to merge into the original. For what it’s worth, when I was working on group projects, we ran into problems with this model and found it easier to work in a shared repo using feature branches. My Q2 group started off working this way, but we got out of sync and had a gnarly merge situation that took a long time to resolve. That was when we switched to feature branches on a shared repo and never looked back.

I used if/else for the entire tax rate problem! I used error checking to handle the exceptions to the case, and then used an if/else inside of the second else to get the results! Sorry that's kind of confusing.
